protocol_name: Ubuntu on Windows for computational biology
protocol_name_html: Ubuntu on Windows for computational biology
description: With the Fall Creators update to Windows 10 comes the ability for all to install Ubuntu on your Windows 10 machine by simply downloading the app from the official Windows App Store. Rather than using a tool like Cygwin, which replicates a UNIX(-like)experience with some of the same command line tools, Ubuntu on Windows is the full Linux experience. Unlike using Cygwin, you can install bioinformatics software like Salmon or Cufflinks with ease. This protocol from Bad Grammar, Good Syntax provides a detailed method of how to install Ubuntu, setting up Python, and installing binaries of software for compbio.
before_start: You need a computer with Windows 10 installed and kept up to date.
keywords: bioinformatics, biology, bash, compbio, Python, RNA
guidelines:
In the past, you could try to dual boot your system so that it has two operating systems or run Ubuntu in a virtual machine within Windows, but I think this method is nice and clean. Others will disagree. 

 

What you won't get is the Ubuntu graphical user interface. You are still stuck with running Windows 10. If that is a problem for you, then dual booting or a virtual machine is probably your best option. Instead, what Ubuntu on Windows offers is a simple way to get access to the command line from Ubuntu. Not only does that mean that you can run software designed and compiled to run on Linux, but you can also use all the cool tools of Ubuntu like apt-get to seamlessly install programs, keep them up-to-date, and fetch dependences. 

 

An alternative guide to Linux on Windows using Conda:
https://github.com/kapsakcj/win10-linux-conda-how-to/blob/master/README.md
status_info: We use this protocol in our group and it is working

source_data.annotation: One thing that you might notice is that you cannot do Ctrl+C or Ctrl+P for copy/paste. This is a pain but to copy text that you have highlighted in the Ubuntu app, you can right-click with your mouse. When you have no texted highlighted, right-click will then paste what you have copied.

source_data.annotation: This is where you wish you had never used spaces in file/folder names, as bash does not handle spaces in filenames well. If this is a big issue for you, I would suggest going back and renaming files/folders you plan to access from the command line.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 10 of Compbio 010: Ubuntu on Windows

source_data.protocol_name_html: Ubuntu on Windows for computational biology
source_data.annotation:
While my version number did not increase, doing this cleared up an issue I was having with some other software I was trying to install - so I advice that you do update it now with the two commands above.

 

If you are new to using a UNIX(-like) system, sudo makes you a superuser: you are able to change important things in you system you cannot do normally. It will ask for your password you set Ubuntu up with.

components.data: Setting up Python
components.name: Section

components.data: If you use a lot of Python in your work, it is rather simple to get Python running on Ubuntu. There are many ways to install Python. One way would be to use Ubuntu's apt-get. Another way is to use Conda. Each of these methods installs Python in a different environment, so just be aware. Ubuntu comes with an install of Python 3 out of the box
components.name: Description

source_data.description: If you use a lot of Python in your work, it is rather simple to get Python running on Ubuntu. There are many ways to install Python. One way would be to use Ubuntu's apt-get. Another way is to use Conda. Each of these methods installs Python in a different environment, so just be aware. Ubuntu comes with an install of Python 3 out of the box

components.data: Setting up Python
components.name: Section

components.data: With advice from here, install these very useful tools for Python on Ubuntu:
components.name: Description

source_data.description: With advice from here, install these very useful tools for Python on Ubuntu:

source_data.name:
$ sudo apt-get install build-essential
$ sudo apt-get install python-dev
$ sudo apt-get install python3-dev

components.data: Setting up Python
components.name: Section

components.data: Now for something really important, to install pip. pip is the official package manager for Python modules.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Now for something really important, to install pip. pip is the official package manager for Python modules.

source_data.name:
$ sudo apt-get install python-pip
$ sudo apt-get install python3-pip

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 15 of Compbio 010: Ubuntu on Windows
source_data.protocol_name: Ubuntu on Windows for computational biology
source_data.protocol_name_html: Ubuntu on Windows for computational biology
source_data.annotation:
It makes installing new packages for Python SOOOO much easier in the long run. 

 

The issue with apt-get is that while it deals with all of the dependency issues (which is really important), it usually installs a really out of date version of the python package. In constrast, pip doesn't deal with the dependencies but it does install the latest version of the package. So I suggest initally installing with apt-get and then updating with pip (see below).

components.data: Installing binaries of software for compbio
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Installing binaries of software for compbio

components.data: There are a number of different programs out there for computational biologists that are not going to be downloadable with apt-get. With these, you might need to download the source code and compile the software yourself. Or you can install them with Conda/bioconda (highly reccomended when possible) or you can down load a pre-compiled binary. You can download a binary and upzip it like so:
components.name: Description

source_data.description: There are a number of different programs out there for computational biologists that are not going to be downloadable with apt-get. With these, you might need to download the source code and compile the software yourself. Or you can install them with Conda/bioconda (highly reccomended when possible) or you can down load a pre-compiled binary. You can download a binary and upzip it like so:

source_data.name:
$ cd /usr/local/bin
$ sudo wget https://github.com/COMBINE-lab/salmon/releases/download/v0.8.2/Salmon-0.8.2_linux_x86_64.tar.gz
$ sudo tar -xvzf Salmon-0.8.2_linux_x86_64.tar.gz

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 21 of Compbio 010: Ubuntu on Windows
source_data.protocol_name: Ubuntu on Windows for computational biology
source_data.protocol_name_html: Ubuntu on Windows for computational biology
source_data.annotation: Luckily, many developers of these tools put out binaries for systems (Mac, Linux, and sometimes even Windows). A binary is a pre-compiled file that you can call to run the program. So here I will go through the simple task of downloading the latest binary for the RNA-seq quantification software Salmon. But a similar approach should work for other programs available as binaries.
source_data.thread_text: Luckily, many developers of these tools put out binaries for systems (Mac, Linux, and sometimes even Windows). A binary is a pre-compiled file that you can call to run the program. So here I will go through the simple task of downloading the latest binary for the RNA-seq quantification software Salmon. But a similar approach should work for other programs available as binaries.
source_data.body: Luckily, many developers of these tools put out binaries for systems (Mac, Linux, and sometimes even Windows). A binary is a pre-compiled file that you can call to run the program. So here I will go through the simple task of downloading the latest binary for the RNA-seq quantification software Salmon. But a similar approach should work for other programs available as binaries.

components.data: Installing binaries of software for compbio
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Installing binaries of software for compbio

components.data: To run Salmon, simply enter the path to the binary in the terminal.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: To run Salmon, simply enter the path to the binary in the terminal.

source_data.name:
/usr/local/bin/Salmon-0.8.2_linux_x86_64/bin/salmon
Salmon v0.8.2
Usage:  salmon -h|--help or
        salmon -v|--version or
        salmon -c|--cite or
        salmon [--no-version-check] <COMMAND> [-h | options]
Commands:
     cite  Show salmon citation information
     index Create a salmon index
     quant Quantify a sample
     swim  Perform super-secret operation

components.data: Installing binaries of software for compbio
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Installing binaries of software for compbio

components.name: Description

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 23 of Compbio 010: Ubuntu on Windows
source_data.protocol_name: Ubuntu on Windows for computational biology
source_data.protocol_name_html: Ubuntu on Windows for computational biology
source_data.annotation: The issue here is having to remember this long path every time you wanted to run Salmon. You could modify your bashrc to add Salmon to your path. But one advantage of entering the path every time, is that you know exactly which version of Salmon (or any software) you are calling every time you use it.
source_data.thread_text: The issue here is having to remember this long path every time you wanted to run Salmon. You could modify your bashrc to add Salmon to your path. But one advantage of entering the path every time, is that you know exactly which version of Salmon (or any software) you are calling every time you use it.
source_data.body: The issue here is having to remember this long path every time you wanted to run Salmon. You could modify your bashrc to add Salmon to your path. But one advantage of entering the path every time, is that you know exactly which version of Salmon (or any software) you are calling every time you use it.
